meta_data.title: - What Do the Two Storms at Sea Have to Do With Faith?
meta_data.subtitle: A Conversation with Dr. Greg Fell

transcription_data.text: BONUS BONUS SEPASO TO BONUS EPISODE Of the 10 minute Bible hour podcast It's a BONUS EPISODE of BONUS EPISODE Of the 10 minute Bible hour podcast Come on now! BONUS Hey everybody I'm Matt, this is the 10 minute Bible hour podcast and we're going to do a fun BONUS EPISODE with a fun BONUS guest My longtime friend Greg Fell, Dr. Greg Fell Let's give him all the credit he's earned Greg, good to see you Good to be here, thank you Greg's awesome, he's been my friend for a long time He's been the district superintendent of the Rocky Mountain District of the Evangelical Free Church of America forever and when I was working at a church he was the guy who helped me figure out how to make things go so I think the world of him and so we got to compare notes today when he was in town and he's like, hey I talked about Matthew 8 today and I was like, wait, the part about the calming of the storm and he was like, yep, and I was like, here talking to this microphone right now and now you, my friends, are caught up on exactly where we are I've been in Matthew 14 we have here in the podcast conversation and we spend a lot of time on this second calming of the storm, this is the walk-on water episode and you just talked about the first of the two episodes what do you see going on in the first one? What is the point? Why is that in the text there in Matthew 8 and do you think there's a connection between it and what's going on in Matthew 14? Oh absolutely Matthew 8, it's all about faith some have it, most don't even the disciples are amazed at what Christ does in the calming of the storm and he says to them, men of little faith what's wrong with you? Why don't you get this? It's an interesting passage because we see both the deity of Christ as well as the humanity of Christ in that passage He's not dumbfounded because he's got in the flesh but socially it comes off like, I mean, what the heck, guys? So what do you see in the text prior to that passage that would make you say that he's justified in having those expectations? It's an interesting day I mean, it starts out he's doing miracles he heals a leper, he heals a paralytic he even heals somebody's mother-in-law one of the leaders says, I'll follow you anywhere and he says, well, yeah, okay, that's great you realize I'm homeless Foxes have holes, birds of the air have nests I don't have any place to lay in my head follow me, he doesn't get into the boat but the disciples follow him they're still trying to figure this guy out they're not expecting the storm, he knows it's coming they're gonna fear for their life before the end of the night and it's a test of their faith how deeply rooted are you? how much do you really believe in me? and it's pretty clear in this first storm they aren't quite with him yet but he doesn't write him off oh no, he doesn't write him off at all it looks like he expects that they've seen enough that they should be able to connect the dots here yeah, they've seen the miracles they've walked with him, they've talked with him yeah, they should know by now, right? but they don't but then he's patient and doesn't blow them up for it you know, then we get to the stuff that we're looking at here in this conversation six chapters later they still are hesitant to acknowledge with words what they are convinced of at least according to the narrative that's the way the text holds it out that's a tremendous amount of patience then that he's demonstrating along the way what are we supposed to glean from that? like at what point are you supposed to have seen enough? well, they're putting their reputations they're very lives on the line because if they start following him they've got some dues to pay with the Sanhedrin, right? right, if we're really going to follow him we're putting everything on the line our lives so in the first one it ends with them being like who's this guy? I mean that even the winds and the waves obey him it's bizarre yeah in the second account well, it's not the second account but in the second incident that's recorded in Matthew 14 this is the one where Jesus walks on the water and Peter gets out of the boat for a minute and they're at that point like they've seen enough and they physically worship him whatever that means is they worshiped him and they said, truly you are the Son of God what changed in your mind over those six chapters? they're on a pilgrimage they're on a journey just like we all are and our faith is something that I think we believe intellectually before we own it they didn't own it yet in chapter 8 what kind of man is this that even the winds and the waves obey him? they're still not quite sure who he is in chapter 8 it's almost like there's a threshold of belief is not a strong enough word a threshold of obviousness that they passed somewhere in there and I couldn't tell you I mean I guess the point is when Peter got out of the boat and walked with Jesus for a second I guess that was the moment you use this phrase all the time I can't remember exactly what it is but it's a phrase about change and you say something like when the pain of one thing outweighs the pain of the other what is that again? the pain of staying the same has to be greater than the pain of change before change will occur I couldn't get the quote right but I was recording this the other day when I was right on this passage I was like oh my buddy Greg says some stuff nope I'm gonna get it wrong I'll just ask him when I talk to him next but I was thinking of that exact quote because to me it seems like what's happening here is they know if they say something that would be blasphemous if it's wrong this person is the son of God and other people hear him say that I mean this isn't your 1960s or 70s America where you can just say anything and it works your book's not gonna get cancelled you are gonna get physically punished for saying the wrong thing about God it's a very risky proclamation to make maybe even a death sentence so some inflection point got passed here where they're like look I can't stop denying what I'm seeing with my eyes look at this thing look at what's happening you just have to say the things that are true and that are in keeping with the evidence that's right in front of your face even if it means a really good beating I think for the modern audience we look at that and it's like well you know they just they just had a heart level experience with the Lord and it was meaningful and it's like maybe a picture like a devotion time like a really nice time of singing at a camp or on a retreat or something but the consequences in the background culturally and historically are so vast for making the proclamation that they make right there I think that their faith is being developed he says to them why are you amazed? why are you surprised at this? you men of little faith their faith grows over time as they experience Jesus they're not quite there yet it's interesting Hebrews 11-1 talks about faith it doesn't say faith is being sure of what we already have and know faith is being sure of what we hope for it's the certainty of what we don't see not what we already know what we've already experienced there's another place of course in scripture where you know Thomas says oh I won't believe unless I see the nail prints in his hands and his feet Jesus walks into the room and he says really here they are you believe because you see blessed are those who believe because they don't see so they're learning that what they are seeing is giving them more hope for what they don't even understand or know so let's say you are sitting in on this conversation right now and you're in a place of faith you're like yeah I'm a Christian I think there's a God behind all this I'm in I think I see Jesus the same way the post walking on water disciples see it what is that person supposed to take from this passage is there anything they do with that or is it just like a yeah high five disciples were on the same page yeah my question is how deep is your faith this is a literal storm but there's a figurative storm also we talk about tough times in our life being a storm we use it as a metaphor right it's really only tested when the storm comes how much do you really believe have you ever asked where are you God what are you doing what what are you up to they're not there yet they're not that deep in their walk with Jesus they don't quite get his deity we see his humanity and his deity in this passage humanity he's asleep in the boat there's this huge storm that's going on and he's had a tough day he's emotionally and physically drained he's sleeping because of the humanity of who he is but we also see his deity here where he has power over the winds in the waves two millennia later we still don't have power to control the weather I think later the passage that you're referring to they get it so it's a process even for a person of faith yeah but what about the person who is fascinated by the Bible isn't quite sure exactly what to make of the claims to deity the miraculous claims here what is a person who's outside looking in what are they supposed to take away from what happens to the disciples between chapter 8 and chapter 14 going from saying who is this to saying surely this is the son of God what if what if they're looking at all of this and they're like I'm tracking I'm reading it I'm looking at it really closely but I'm not sure I'm there well faith is a process of trusting God in those things that we don't understand having him prove himself as he takes us through those experiences and the more we see and feel and understand him working in our life see that's where the roots of faith go deep into the soil and they gain some strength so patience and the long game is okay sure if there's still questions and there's still process to go through even though at this point in the text maybe Matthew is saying hey I was on the boat and this was enough for me at this point like I was there with the guys we all saw what happened we'd seen enough and we were like we're in so Matthew has us there narratively at the end of chapter 14 but we still have half the book to go for the person who wasn't on the boat maybe it's not quite as impactful if you're just hearing the story and maybe for that person if they're not quite to that place yet that Matthew was it's okay for them to continue that process even if it moves a little slower than somebody who was on a boat to see a miracle like that sure as humans we want to be able to test it to touch it to feel it to smell it to measure it before we can believe it particularly in American culture that isn't what faith is Hebrews 11 1 and 2 again it's the substance of things hoped for it's the evidence of things we haven't seen so it isn't ontological it's trusting in that which God proclaims I think there are a ton of people on both sides of that inflection point of faith who I think I think both crowds will find what you've said very helpful I don't view Matthew as giving us the and now we're done with the part where you think about it you know drop of the microphone here in chapter 14 I think he's describing what it was like to be there in the first hand account and the faith process they went through but I think entirely separately he's trying to walk the reader through a process of faith that clearly he anticipates he's only halfway through with this is fun buddy thanks for jumping in with me hey thanks for inviting me you did a great job with zero notice or warning I really like it socially just being like here just talking to this trust me don't think just talk so nice job thinking on your people hey I'm not thinking is my forte yeah okay whatever hey thanks for hanging out with us we'll get back to whatever passage we have up next in Matthew next time around I'm Matt it's my buddy Greg Fell this is the 10 minute Bible hour podcast do this again soon my friends
